text: in 2009 a carrier pigeon named Winston
was tasked with an abnormal request on a
typical day Winston would be responsible
for carrying messages across hundreds of
miles these messages were pretty concise
usually around a paragraph long on this
day however Winston was set to carry
much more data and with it make
history the total size of data that
Winston was tasked with on this abnormal
request was 4 GB that's around the size
of an HD movie for comparison the size
of a normal message that Winston would
carry would be between 50 and 250 bytes
therefore on this trip Winston was
carrying around 10 million times more
data this data was placed on an SD card
and strapped to Winston's leg his goal
was to take the data from the town of
Peter maritzburg in South Africa to the
coastal town of Durban about 60 Mi away
now you're probably thinking why the
effort surely it's easier to load the
data onto a computer and just send it
over the Internet well what if I told
you it was an emergency and on the SD
card was vital data needed to save
someone's life whilst the internet was
down I'd be lying of course but it would
make a good story the real reason was
because it was a test a test to see
which was faster Winston the carrier
pigeon or the leading internet service
provider in South Africa Telcom whoever
managed to get the data on on to the
destination computer first would be
crowned the winner all in all loading
the data onto the SD card strapping it
on to Winston's feathery leg and
uploading it at the destination took
around 2 hours 6 minutes and 57 seconds
that's a total transfer speed of about
4.2 megabits per second for reference
that's about 1/5 to 1 16th the median
upload speed in 20123 nothing amazing
but nothing to scoff at either given
this was done with an actual live bird
so how did Winston's competitor Telcom
Fair well in that time they had only
managed to transfer 4% of the data to
the same destination this gave the ISP
an average speed of about 0.17 megabits
per second or 170 kilobits per second
pretty embarrassing to be honest so the
ISP lost substantially now it's easy to
jump to conclusions and blame it on bad
infrastructure within South Africa but
Telcom wasn't the only one to be bested
by this unconventional speed test
in fact ET or British Telecom the
largest ISP in the UK at the time also
had its feathers ruffled in
2010 in this case it was a small army of
birds with 10 pigeons carrying USB
sticks competing against the ISP to
upload a 5minute video of which was
around 300 megabytes in total by the
time the pigeons had landed the video
upload was only 24% complete another win
for our feathery friends so why are
people using this unconventional speed
test against their isps well in the case
of the UK it was to highlight issues
with internet speeds in rural areas and
was heavily influenced by the test in
South Africa the South African test was
actually organized by an IT company
based in Durban called unlimited it but
where did the idea to use a carrier
pigeon come from it's not like speed
tests didn't exist back in 2009 well
there's some conflicting reports one is
that an employee who was just one day
complaining about the speed of the
internet that day claimed a carrier
pigeon would be faster however I am a
little skeptical of this story and other
reports claim it was based on an old
internet joke before we look into this
joke however let's take a step back and
talk about the noble rockov aka the
carrier pigeon pigeons have often gotten
a bad rep having lived in London for a
period of my life I've often heard them
be referred to as Rats of the sky
however they're also known as The Rock
Dove which gives us a clue as to why
they prefer our concrete cities this
alongside the fact that there tends to
be a lot of food around where humans
live Mak cities the perfect habitat for
pigeons to call their home the history
of pigeons and humans goes far beyond
our concrete jungles however in fact way
before the internet even existed humans
have used pigeons to carry messages
throughout history some of the earliest
references are back in ancient Egypt in
3000 BCE pigeons have also performed
important tasks such as carrying
messages during times of war and
announcing the winners of ancient
Olympics pigeons are used due to their
incredible ability to return home even
when transported hundreds of miles away
in addition to this if a pigeon knows as
a reliable food source it will travel
hundreds of miles to get there using
these two abilities humans have
effectively trained pigeons to carry
messages between two points thus
creating what could be considered the
first internet of course these pigeons
could easily be be intercepted and their
messages taken to counter this
encryption was used in order to secure
the content of messages but that's a
story for another time so where did the
inspiration for Winston's Epic Journey
come from well back in 1990 nearly 20
years or two carrier pigeon lifetimes
before Winston made his journey a
request for comment or RFC numbered 1149
was proposed rfc's are technical
documentation used to set the standards
of how the internet works this proposal
was called the IP over avien carriers
proposal or ipac in which internet
traffic would be carried by birds such
as R Winston this proposal was issued by
the internet engineering task force on
the 1st of April
1990 that date is important The Proposal
was obviously a joke however as I
mentioned in my previous video on the
weirdest HTTP status codes do not give
developers bad jokes however this rule
was once again broken and like an
unguarded sandwich in the middle of a
large city the pigeons were brought in
on the 28th of April 2001 11 years after
the original proposal the RFC was
implemented by the Bergen Linux User
Group in which they adopted a prototype
called cpip which stood for carrier
pigeon Internet Protocol you really
cannot trust developers can you the
group sent nine packets of data over a
distance of approximately 3 miles each
one carried by an individual pigeon
after some time they received their
packet responses of the nine requests
they only received four ping replies due
to various different reasons at the end
of it they had a packet loss of around
55% which isn't great but it's not
terrible however the latency was
incredibly high with the response time
ranging between 3,000 and 6,000 seconds
roughly 1 to 2 hours regardless of the
results the RFC had been successfully
implemented but that wasn't the end of
it and since the original proposal
additional rfc's were created the first
of these was RFC
2549 this proposal was written by the
same author of the original RFC and
sought to bring four different quality
levels of service ranging from Concord
first class business class and Coach
Additionally the RFC suggested that
heavy users of the protocol could earn
frequent flyer miles in case you haven't
realized developers love to push a joke
as far as they possibly can in addition
to this as the original RFC only
supported ipv4 RFC 6214 was released
extending the protocol for
IPv6 however despite these improvements
the protocol does come with some risks
take for instance back in 2005 when bird
flu Mania was all the rage during this
time a Gartner report concluded that the
pandemic would likely have little impact
on it systems directly this report was
criticized humorously for being
uninformed and neglecting the IP over
Aven carrier protocols as well as bird
flu other known risks include Birds of
Prey strong winds unguarded sandwiches
and general bad weather thus making IP
over AC a little less reliable than our
current systems despite these risks
however Winston was notable as a marked
improvement to the original
implementation although as the RFC
described using paper with the pigeons
instead of SD cards Winston and his
predecessors were criticized for
breaking the original standard but you
know what I say rules are meant to be
broken and Winston will forever hold a
place in my heart as a winner I want to
give a quick shout out to my latest
Channel member spread prism a big thank
you to both you and my existing channel
members for helping to support this
channel otherwise a big thank you to
everyone else for watching and I'll see
you on the next one
